It is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves, which are adaptations to its arid or semi-arid habitat. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically white or pale pink, adding to its ornamental appeal. Zootrophion hirtzii is often found in rocky or sandy soils, thriving in well-drained environments.
